title: Introduction to the tidyverse
text:
Summary
I was invited by Professor Vincent Arel-Bundock as a guest lecturer to lead a three-hour workshop for the FAS 3001 - Statistiques avancées en sciences sociales course. The workshop focused on data wrangling with dplyr and visualization with ggplot2. I also shared insights into my non-linear career trajectory and discussed how I use R at the research institute.

title: Introduction to R and the tidyverse
text:
Summary
As a member of R-Ladies Ottawa, I developed and led a series of virtual workshops aimed at introducing novice programmers to base R and popular tidyverse packages. These sessions attracted participants not only from Ottawa but also from around the world.
With the generous support of the R-Ladies Global team, we were able to test drive their Posit Cloud environment, which eliminated the need for participants to install software on their local machines. This significantly lowered the barrier to entry, allowing participants to focus on learning without the technical hurdles of software installation.

title: nRc: a collaborative coding group
text:
Summary
As a member of the Women in Science and Innovation peer group at National Research Council Canada (NRC), I noticed a strong interest in an introductory R course. Together with my colleagues, Jenna Mackinnon and Solenn Mordret, I co-organized a four-part virtual workshop covering the fundamentals of base R as well as data wrangling and visualization using popular packages like dplyr and ggplot2. Our priority was to create a welcoming environment, assisting participants with software installation and providing communication in both official languages.
With over 50 women participating from various cities and research centers across Canada, our initiative garnered recognition from NRC executives. As a result, my co-organizers and I were invited to participate in a panel discussion focused on coding at the Celebrating the Success of Women in STEM Symposium held on February 9, 2024.

title: Bringing analysts and technical writers together through internal packages
text:
About the conference
Cascadia R is a regional R conference serving the Pacific Northwest. In 2021, the event took place online on June 4 and 5. I had the opportunity to reflect on my experience at the Office of the Provincial Health Officer in British Columbia through a five-minute lightning talk.

title: Bringing analysts and technical writers together through internal packages
text:
What I presented
This abstract has been edited for conciseness
Restructuring frequently used code snippets into well-organized internal packages is easier said than done. In this presentation, we discuss how to address challenges that are less explored compared to the technical aspects of the development process. How do you find out what your team truly needs? And once the package is complete, how do you encourage colleagues to adopt it?
We answer these questions through a case study reflecting on our team’s experience creating a ggplot2 extension to match the organization’s existing style guide for healthcare utilization reports. This package streamlines plot formatting, allowing analysts to focus on identifying trends in the data to share with technical writers, thereby fostering more efficient collaboration between the two groups.

title: R-Ladies RoCur (Rotating Curation)
text:
Each week, a different useR took over the @WeAreRLadies Twitter account to share their experiences using R. Featured curators came from a wide range of professions and had a wide variety of experience in R. The program has since left Twitter and moved to Bluesky.
From October 17 to October 22, 2022, I tweeted about how to develop packages, ensure code reproducibility, and organize coding workshops. My tweet about writing ggplot2 extensions was particularly well received, garnering hundreds of likes!

title: R Project Sprint 2023
text:
Summary
The R Project Sprint took place at the University of Warwick from August 30 to September 1, 2023. It brought together 46 participants, including members of the R Core team, to collaboratively contribute to base R. This included tasks such as fixing bugs, improving documentation, and working on message translations (i.e., internationalization).
During the event, I focused on assisting with the English-to-Japanese translation of messages in base R and packages supplied with the R distribution. The event offered me a valuable opportunity to learn from useRs who teach coding in non-English environments and deepened my appreciation for the extensive coordination required to maintain open-source software.
For more insights, check out this excellent blog post by Shannon Pileggi.

title: Reiko Okamoto
text: My name is Reiko and I’m a creative implementer passionate about reproducible data analysis. I find a lot of joy in making sense of complex clinical and administrative data, helping collaborators transform their research questions into insights through code. I’m also involved with R-Ladies Ottawa, where I help organize events that make coding more accessible and create opportunities for data enthusiasts to connect in the National Capital Region. When I’m not at my computer, you’ll probably find me travelling, trainspotting, or training to be on the next season of The Amazing Race Canada.

title: Developing R packages for yourself and others
text:
Summary
In this 2-hour virtual workshop, participants developed a simple R package to gain hands-on experience, following best practices outlined in R Packages by Hadley Wickham and Jennifer Bryan.
In addition to covering the technical aspects of package development (e.g., structuring, documenting, and testing code), I shared insights from my experience developing an R package for the Office of the Provincial Health Officer in British Columbia. This included strategies for aligning features with the needs of a team and encouraging package adoption within an organization.
Participants left the workshop with both practical skills for creating R packages and actionable tips for fostering collaboration in professional settings.

title: What an early 2000s reality show taught me about file management
text:
About the conference
posit::conf(2023) took place in Chicago, USA from September 17 to 20, 2023. As one of the largest conferences in the R community, this event offers a unique opportunity to learn about new tools and foster connections within the open-source community. The event featured a diverse program, including workshops keynotes, and presentations.
I had the privilege of attending as both a speaker and an Opportunity Scholar. During the conference, I had the chance to connect with fellow Opportunity Scholarship recipients and members of the R-Ladies community from around the world.

title: What an early 2000s reality show taught me about file management
text:
What I presented
This abstract has been edited for conciseness
Ideas from home organization shows are surprisingly applicable to file management. Using a room divider in a studio to establish dedicated zones for different activities is analogous to creating self-contained projects. Likewise, swapping mismatched hangers with matching ones resembles the adoption of a file naming convention to make a directory easier to navigate.
In this talk, I will share good practices in file management through the lens of home organization. We all know that clutter, whether it is in our physical space or on our machine, impacts our ability to focus. These practices will help useRs create a serene, relaxing environment where they feel inspired to work with data.

title: Table talk: reproducible table creation in R for epidemiological research
text:
About the conference
useR! 2024 took place in Salzburg, Austria from July 8 to 11, 2024. The conference’s 20th anniversary brought together R users from around the world, featuring presentations that showcased the latest advancements and applications of the programming language. I was honoured to have my submission selected for a five-minute lightning talk.

title: Table talk: reproducible table creation in R for epidemiological research
text:
What I presented
This abstract has been edited for conciseness
Summary tables are common in scientific manuscripts reporting epidemiological studies. Table 1 typically displays key demographic information about the study population while Table 2 often presents associations between explanatory and outcome variables. Given the variety of ways to create these tables in R (some more robust than others), our research group developed a reproducible workflow suitable for colleagues with varying levels of R proficiency.
In this talk, I will discuss the landscape of table-generating packages, present our solution, and explain how we overcame challenges like incorporating existing metadata. These strategies are not only valuable for epidemiologists but also for researchers in other health and social sciences.
